answers.answer: This is suggestive of issues with decreased cognitive functions.  Do you have Diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol/high fat diet, history of dementia (in family) or are you a smoker?  Who ordered the MRI your PCP?  Probably should get a referral to a neurologist if you don't have one already! Nothing going on is acute, more long term issue instead.

Neurologist ordered MRI. None of the above disorders and never smoked in life. Symptoms include memory loss, confusion,getting stuck mid-sentence and forgetfulness. Does MRI correlate with symptoms and is MRI results age appropriate????Thanks for your time.MIke

Your age group is right around the time when people start showing some signs of dementia (alzheimer's), for those people diagnosed with it, yes.  However, it is NOT normal for a 49 year old or even older people.  Your neurologist most likely will not be surprised at those findings based on your symptoms.  I wish you luck, and you're quite welcome!

question: Please advise on anything that I should be concerned. Note, 49 yr old male.Findings: Diffuse cerebral volume loss with commensurate enlargementof the ventricles is present. Sulcal widening and sylvian fissurewidening is symmetrical throughout the left and right cerebrum. Thecorpus callosum is normal in thickness. The hippocampi aresymmetrical in size. The cortical fissures and the temporal hornsare also symmetrical in size. There is no abnormal signal present inthe brain parenchyma. The sella, pineal, and cervicomedullary regionsare unremarkable. There is no acute intracranial hemorrhage orevidence of acute infarction. Neither mass lesion, shift of midlinestructures, nor abnormal extra-axial fluid collections are present.Flow voids of the major intracranial arterial vessels are identified.Imaged portions of the paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells areclear. The orbits are unremarkable.ImpressionImpression: Diffuse symmetrical cerebral volume loss. There is noacute intracranial disease process.
title: MRI Interpretation
